questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of seizures and musty-smelling urine. His immunizations are up-to-date. His height and weight are both below the 10th percentile. He is pale and has blue eyes. He cannot pull himself up from a seated position to stand and does not crawl. Which of the following genetic principles best explains the variety of phenotypic traits seen in this patient?

He is asymptomatic but concerned about his risk. Colonoscopy reveals no significant polyposis. This patient most likely has a defect in which of the following pathways?

questions.solution: Ans. A) Binding of carbon monoxide to myoglobin

questions.text: What is the seventh enzyme class as per The International Union of Biochemistry (IUBMB) classification of enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Translocases

 

The International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB) classifies enzymes into seven major classes based on the type of reaction they catalyze. The seventh enzyme class—added in 2018—is Translocases. These enzymes catalyze the movement of ions, molecules, or macromolecules across membranes or their separation within membranes, often coupled with ATP hydrolysis or ion gradients. Examples include ATP synthase (which translocates protons) and ABC transporters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lyases: Incorrect. Lyases are class 4 enzymes that catalyze the addition or removal of groups to form double bonds without hydrolysis or oxidation (e.g., fumarase, aldolase).

 

Option B. Isomerases: Incorrect. Isomerases are class 5 enzymes that catalyze intramolecular rearrangements, converting one isomer into another (e.g., phosphohexose isomerase).

 

Option C. Ligases: Incorrect. Ligases are class 6 enzymes that join two molecules together using energy from ATP hydrolysis (e.g., DNA ligase, synthetases). 

 

Summary:

choices.text: Mutation in the Galectin-3 promoter region
Decreased methylation of the Galectin-3 gene
Shortening of the Galectin-3 mRNA poly-(A) tail
Decreased ubiquitination of the Galectin-3 protein

questions.text:
Researchers are working to identify new targets for drug development to treat idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. After obtaining lung tissue samples from affected patients, they conduct a series of experiments to measure the expression and activity of various profibrotic proteins. The results for one such protein, galectin-3, are as follows:

 

  • mRNA concentration: Normal
  • Protein concentration: Increased
  • Protein activity: Intact

 

Which of the following processes best explains these findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Decreased ubiquitination of the Galectin-3 protein

questions.text: Which of the following depicts the correct sequence of enzymes involved in glycogenolysis in the liver?

A 25-year-old man with a history of solvent abuse presents with fatigue and frequent exposure to toluene. Laboratory tests reveal elevated hippuric acid in his urine. Hippuric acid is formed by the conjugation of which of the following compounds?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benzoyl glycine

 

  • Hippuric acid is a compound formed in the liver through the conjugation of benzoic acid with glycine.
  • This process occurs as part of the body’s detoxification pathway, particularly for substances like toluene, which is metabolized to benzoic acid. 
  • Benzoic acid undergoes conjugation via the enzyme glycine N-acyltransferase, leading to the formation of benzoyl glycine (hippuric acid). 
  • Hippuric acid is then excreted in the urine as a detoxified product.
  • Clinically, elevated hippuric acid levels can serve as a marker for toluene exposure, commonly seen in individuals with solvent abuse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benzoyl acetate: Benzoyl acetate does not participate in the metabolism of benzoic acid or in hippuric acid formation. It is not involved in the conjugation pathway with glycine.

 

Option C. Benzoyl lactate: Benzoyl lactate is not a known intermediate or product in the metabolic pathway of benzoic acid. Lactate is typically associated with anaerobic metabolism, not detoxification pathways.

 

Option D. Benzoyl glutamine: While glutamine is involved in ammonia detoxification and urea cycle processes, it does not conjugate with benzoic acid to form hippuric acid. The conjugating partner in this case is glycine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hippuric acid is formed by the conjugation of benzoic acid with glycine in the liver and is excreted in urine. 
  • It serves as a clinical marker for toluene exposure or benzoic acid metabolism.

questions.solution: Ans. C) α(1→4) linkage; α(1→6) linkage

questions.text: A 12-month-old male baby presents with vomiting, lethargy on consuming fruit juice. Which of the following can give a positive reaction in this patient's condition that is most diagnostic?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seliwanoff's reagent 

 

This child likely has hereditary fructose intolerance, caused by a deficiency of aldolase B. When fructose-containing foods (like fruit juice) are consumed, fructose-1-phosphate accumulates in the liver, leading to hypoglycemia, vomiting, and lethargy. Seliwanoff’s test specifically detects ketohexoses such as fructose. When treated with Seliwanoff’s reagent (resorcinol and concentrated HCl), fructose gives a rapid cherry-red color, making this the most diagnostic test for detecting fructose in urine or serum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benedict’s test: Incorrect. Benedict’s test detects reducing sugars (e.g., glucose, galactose, fructose), but it cannot differentiate between them, so it is nonspecific for fructose.

 

Option C. Sakaguchi’s reagent: Incorrect. Sakaguchi’s test is used for detecting arginine (a basic amino acid) and has no role in identifying carbohydrate metabolism disorders.

 

Option D. Millon’s reagent: Incorrect. Millon’s test detects tyrosine residues in proteins due to their phenolic group, producing a red coloration. It is unrelated to sugar metabolism or fructose detection.

choices.text: Elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids

questions.text: A 2-months-old infant is found to be hypotonic. On examination, there is a large anterior fontanelle and hepatomegaly. Further investigations confirmed a diagnosis of the cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which of the following is not a biochemical finding in this case?
Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MuTL

 

MuTL is not involved in the double-strand DNA break (DSB) repair mechanism. Instead, MuTL is part of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) system, which corrects base-pair mismatches and small insertion–deletion loops that arise during DNA replication. It works together with MutS homologs to recognize and excise mismatched bases — a process distinct from DSB repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRE11: Correct. MRE11, part of the MRN complex (MRE11–RAD50–NBS1), plays a critical role in detecting and processing double-strand breaks. It helps in resection of DNA ends to initiate homologous recombination repair.

 

Option B. BRCA1: Correct. BRCA1 is essential in homologous recombination (HR) repair of double-strand breaks. It facilitates DNA end resection and coordinates repair with other HR proteins like RAD51.

 

Option C. KU80: Correct. KU80, along with KU70, forms the Ku heterodimer that binds to DNA ends and recruits DNA-PKcs during non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), the main DSB repair pathway in non-dividing cells.

Richner-Hanhart syndrome is associated with a defect in which of the following?
Match the incorrect pair of drugs and enzyme/reaction they inhibit:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5FU: Dihydrofolate reductase

 

5-FU inhibits thymidylate synthase, not DHFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: PRPP synthetase: Azathioprine → Inhibits purine synthesis via PRPP amidotransferase.

 

Option B. Mycophenolate: IMP → GMP conversion: Mycophenolate → Inhibits IMP dehydrogenase (IMP → GMP).

 

Option C. Leflunomide: Carbamoyl phosphate → Orotic acid: Leflunomide → Inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase in pyrimidine synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a glycolipid?
All of the following reactions may be inhibited in an alcoholic except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lactic acid production

 

In alcoholism, lactic acid production is not inhibited; in fact, it is enhanced. Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD⁺ ratio in the liver due to oxidation of ethanol by alcohol dehydrogenase and acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. The excess NADH shifts pyruvate toward lactate formation (via lactate dehydrogenase), leading to lactic acidosis. Therefore, lactic acid production continues or even increases, making this the exception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolysis: Inhibited indirectly because the high NADH levels slow the conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate, thus impairing energy metabolism in hepatocytes.

 

Option B. TCA: Inhibited because high NADH inhibits key dehydrogenases (isocitrate, α-ketoglutarate, and malate dehydrogenase), reducing TCA cycle activity.

 

Option D. Fatty acid oxidation: Inhibited as the increased NADH/NAD⁺ ratio suppresses β-oxidation, leading to fatty acid accumulation and hepatic steatosis (fatty liver).

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

This question describes a “suppressor mutation” — a secondary mutation that compensates for the effect of the original (primary) mutation, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype even though the original mutation remains.

 

  • A mutation in a tRNA gene can change its anticodon, allowing the altered tRNA to recognize the stop codon and insert an amino acid instead of stopping translation.
  • This allows the ribosome to “read through” the stop codon and complete synthesis of the full-length protein, restoring the wild-type phenotype.

→ This tRNA mutation is thus a “suppressor mutation”.

 

Example

 

Original mutation:

 

  • Wild-type codon: UAC (codes for tyrosine)
  • Mutant codon: UAG (stop codon → premature termination)

 

Suppressor tRNA mutation:

 

  • A tRNA anticodon mutates to AUC, enabling it to pair with UAG and insert tyrosine again.
  • The protein is synthesized normally → phenotypic reversion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene:

  • A frameshift mutation alters the reading frame of the entire gene by adding or deleting nucleotides not in multiples of three.
  • This changes all downstream codons, usually producing a completely nonfunctional protein.
  • A second frameshift rarely restores normal reading frame or function, so this mechanism does not suppress the original mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene:

 

  • Introducing a separate normal (wild-type) gene copy allows normal protein production through gene complementation.
  • However, this does not correct or suppress the effect of the original mutant gene—it simply provides an additional functioning version.
  • Therefore, it is not considered a true suppressor mutation.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene:

 

  • Deleting the defective gene merely removes it from the genome and stops its abnormal expression.
  • This does not compensate for the lost function or restore the original phenotype produced by the mutant allele.
